questions.statement: Which of the following can be operands of arithmetic operators?
questions.explain: The operand of arithmetic operators can be any of numeric or character type, But not boolean.

questions.statement: Modulus operator, %, can be applied to which of these?
options: Both Integers and floating – point numbers.
correctAns: Both Integers and floating – point numbers.
questions.explain: Modulus operator can be applied to both integers and floating point numbers.

questions.statement: With x = 0, which of the following are legal lines of Java code for changing the value of x to 1?
questions.explain: Operator ++ increases value of variable by 1. x = x + 1 can also be written in shorthand form as x += 1. Also x =+ 1 will set the value of x to 1.

questions.statement: Decrement operator, −−, decreases value of variable by what number?
Which of these statements are incorrect?
options: Assignment operators are more efficiently implemented by Java run-time system than their equivalent long forms.
Assignment operators run faster than their equivalent long forms.
Assignment operators can be used only with numeric and character data type.

questions.statement: What is the output of this program?

questions.explain: Modulus operator returns the remainder of a division operation on the operand. a = a % 10 returns 25.64 % 10 i:e 5.640000000000001. Similarly b = b % 10 returns 5.

questions.explain: Operator ++ has more preference than *, thus g becomes 4 and when multiplied by 8 gives 32.

questions.statement: Can 8 byte long data type be automatically type cast to 4 byte float data type?
questions.explain: Both data types have different memory representation that’s why 8-byte integral data type can be stored to 4-byte floating point data type.
